title: HTML comments lost during incremental writes
description: HTML comments (<\!-- ... -->) are dropped from the Pandoc AST during parsing. tree-sitter parses them as 'comment' nodes which become IntermediateUnknown and are silently removed. This causes comments to be lost when the incremental writer rewrites blocks containing comments. Block-level standalone comments survive as empty Para blocks (preserved via source spans on KeepBefore), but inline comments within paragraphs are completely gone.

title: Phase 5: Inline splicing for incremental writer

When a reconciliation plan involves changes that neither add nor remove nodes that create newline characters (SoftBreak, LineBreak), indentation boundaries are preserved and inline changes can be spliced without rewriting the entire indentation boundary. This is a critical optimization for the common case of text edits within paragraphs inside lists and block quotes. Plan: claude-notes/plans/2026-02-10-inline-splicing.md

title: Suppress auto-generated header IDs in QMD writer roundtrips
description: Headers like '## project {.a-class}' roundtrip as '## project {#project .a-class}', adding an auto-generated ID that wasn't in the source. title: Incremental QMD writer for localized AST-to-string updates
description: Design and implement an incremental writer for pampa that converts localized AST changes into localized string edits. When an AST node changes, only the corresponding portion of the QMD string should be rewritten, preserving the rest of the original source text. Key challenge: markdown's indentation-sensitive constructs (block quotes, lists) mean inner node source spans are non-contiguous, requiring a 'loosened incrementality' approach.

title: Div transforms (definition-list, list-table) not applied to JSON input

This means divs with 'definition-list' or 'list-table' classes are not converted to their proper AST representations when processing JSON input.

title: Table caption parsing fails without blank line before caption
description:
Table captions using the colon syntax require a blank line before the caption line, but Pandoc doesn't require this. Example that fails: '| Header |
|--------|
| Data   |
: Caption'. Works with blank line: '| Header |
|--------|
| Data   |

: Caption'. This is a parser-level issue in the tree-sitter grammar or processing.
notes:
ROOT CAUSE IDENTIFIED:

The caption rule in grammar.js:257 requires $._blank_line as first element. When no blank line precedes ': Caption', the pipe table parser treats ':' as valid punctuation in cell contents, creating an extra table row instead of a caption.

KEY INSIGHT: In qmd, ': ' at line start is ONLY used for captions (no definition lists). This means zero ambiguity - we can safely recognize captions without requiring blank lines.

SOLUTION: Two-part fix:
1. Remove blank line requirement from caption grammar rule
2. Modify external scanner to terminate pipe tables when next line starts with ': ' (single colon for caption, not '::' for fenced div)

See detailed plan: claude-notes/plans/2025-10-27-table-caption-blank-line-fix.md

title: Implement schema compilation with registry support
description:
Implement Schema::compile() method that resolves eager references and merges inheritance at compilation time. This enables two-phase schema processing: (1) stateless parsing without registry, (2) compilation with registry that produces structurally complete schemas ready for validation.

Key components:
- Schema::compile(&registry) method with recursive compilation
- Resolve eager refs (resolveRef) during compilation
- Keep lazy refs (ref) for validation-time resolution
- Support circular lazy references
- Error handling for missing eager refs and circular eager refs
- Comprehensive tests with real quarto-cli schemas

See claude-notes/designs/2025-10-27-schema-compilation-phase.md for full design.

Estimated: 4-6 hours

- ValidationError → DiagnosticMessage conversion loses machine-readable structure
- JSON output is just rendered DiagnosticMessage, not purpose-built
- Missing: full source ranges, schema paths, instance paths in structured format

**Goal**:
- Validator returns rich error struct with all information
- Error struct can be rendered for humans (ariadne) or machines (JSON)
- JSON output has full source ranges, paths, filenames in machine-readable format

title: Implement smart terminal color detection using OSC 10/11 queries
description:
Terminals support querying their current foreground/background colors using OSC 10/11 escape sequences. This could enable smart color selection in the ANSI writer.

Implementation would:
- Query terminal colors using \x1b]10;?\x1b\ and \x1b]11;?\x1b\
- Parse RGB response format (rgb:RRRR/GGGG/BBBB)
- Detect dark vs light backgrounds
- Adapt color palette for better contrast
- Fall back to current defaults if query fails

Challenges:
- Requires raw terminal mode
- Not available in pipes/redirects
- Adds complexity and latency
- Should be behind feature flag

See claude-notes/terminal-color-querying.md for detailed research and implementation notes.

title: Fix backslash escape handling in pandoc_str
description:

**Current behavior**:
Input: hello\*world

Pandoc output: Str "hello*world" (backslash consumed)

**Root cause**:
The tree-sitter grammar captures backslashes as part of pandoc_str (see regex with \\. at tree-sitter-markdown/grammar.js:531). They need post-processing to convert escape sequences to literal characters.

**Investigation needed**:
- Determine if backslashes should be in separate backslash_escape nodes or handled within pandoc_str
- Check if the grammar needs changes or just the handler logic
- Add comprehensive tests for all escapable characters

**Context**: Discovered during tree-sitter refactoring (k-274). See also: claude-notes/plans/2025-10-31-tree-sitter-qmd-cleanup-completion.md which mentions this as future work.

**Estimate**: 2-3 hours (investigation + fix + tests)

- **Full compliance**: Passes 652/652 CommonMark 0.31.2 spec tests
- **Critical**: Must configure for CommonMark-only mode (disable GFM extensions)
- See claude-notes/plans/2025-11-06-comrak-ast-structure.md for detailed AST analysis

APPROACH: Whitelist subset where qmd_subset ⊂ qmd AND qmd_subset ⊂ CommonMark

INCLUDED: ATX headings, fenced code, emphasis/strong, inline links, lists, blockquotes, hr
EXCLUDED: qmd features (divs, callouts), edge cases (Setext, indented code, HTML, reference links)

SEMANTIC GRAMMAR: Define subset in terms of abstract semantic structure (Document, Block, Inline, etc.)
- Level 3: Abstract semantic structure (what we promise)
- Level 4: Pandoc AST (how we verify - secondary test)
- Level 5: HTML output (primary test - matches CommonMark spec)
- Level 2: Tree-sitter CST (implementation detail - NOT what we promise)

TESTING: 
- Primary: HTML output comparison (comrak HTML vs qmd HTML)
- Secondary: Pandoc AST equivalence (comrak → HTML → Pandoc vs qmd → Pandoc)
- Both using comrak configured for pure CommonMark (no GFM)

title: Fix parser handling of multi-byte emoji characters
description:
The tree-sitter grammar fails to parse multi-byte emoji characters (particularly numbered emojis like 1️⃣, 2️⃣, 3️⃣).

**Minimal reproduction**:
```markdown
::: {.content-visible when-profile="fr"}
1️⃣ Trouver le tableau
:::
```

**Error**: 'Parse error: unexpected character or token here' at the emoji position

**Technical details**:
- Emoji like 1️⃣ is a multi-byte UTF-8 sequence:
  - Digit '1' (U+0031): `31`
  - Variation Selector-16 (U+FE0F): `efb88f`
  - Combining Enclosing Keycap (U+20E3): `e283a3`
- Simplified emoji test cases parse correctly
- Error only occurs in real corpus files with complex context
- Likely issue with tree-sitter grammar's UTF-8 handling in certain states

title: Implement basic template evaluator
description:

Initial scope (no pipes, no partials):

- Conditionals -> evaluate truthiness, render appropriate branch
- For loops -> iterate over arrays/maps, render body for each

- evaluate(template: &[TemplateNode], context: &TemplateContext) -> Result<String>
- resolve_variable(var: &VariableRef, context: &TemplateContext) -> TemplateValue
- render_value(value: &TemplateValue) -> String

For loop semantics:
- Array: iterate over elements, bind to variable name and 'it'
- Map: single iteration with map as context
- Other: single iteration with value

4. Handle nested conditionals correctly

   - Map: single iteration with map as context
   - Other: single iteration with value

4. Render loop body for each iteration
5. Insert separator between iterations (not after last)
6. Handle nested loops correctly via context scoping

Per Pandoc semantics:
- Inside loop, can use either $variable$ or $it$ to refer to current element
- For nested access: $variable.field$ or $it.field$

title: Implement nesting/indentation in evaluator
description:
Implement nesting directive ($^$) for multi-line indentation in the template evaluator.

The nesting directive ensures subsequent lines are indented to line up with the first line.

Example:
  $item.number$  $^$$item.description$
produces:
  00123  A fine bottle of 18-year old
         Oban whiskey.

Tasks:
1. Track current column position during rendering
2. When encountering $^$, record current column as indentation level
3. For content after $^$, indent subsequent lines to this level
4. Handle nested nesting directives

Design consideration: The Haskell implementation uses Doc type with DL.nest for this. Our initial implementation can use a simpler approach by:
- Tracking indentation level as state
- Post-processing multi-line strings to add indentation

Note: Full fidelity with Pandoc's Doc-based approach may require future refactoring.

title: Implement breakable spaces in evaluator

Per Pandoc documentation:
'When rendering to a Doc, a distinction can be made between breakable and unbreakable spaces. Normally, spaces in the template itself are not breakable, but they can be made breakable in part of the template by using the ~ keyword.'

'The ~ keyword has no effect when rendering to Text or String.'

Tasks:
1. For String output (current approach): Simply render content as-is (spaces are not breakable)
2. If/when we implement Doc output: Mark spaces as breakable using DL.space equivalent

Design note: This feature is only meaningful when templates produce Doc output that can be reflowed. For simple String rendering, this is a no-op that just passes through content.

Priority: Lower than other evaluator tasks since it's effectively a no-op for String output.

design:
## RawInline/RawBlock
- Echo contents if format is 'plaintext', otherwise drop with warning

## PlainTextWriterContext
- Thread error diagnostics through all write functions
- Convenience functions return (String, Vec<DiagnosticMessage>)

## Inlines - Strip structure, keep content:
- Str, Space, SoftBreak, LineBreak: output directly
- Emph, Strong, Underline, Strikeout, Superscript, Subscript, SmallCaps, Span: recurse (no markers)
- Quoted: use actual quote characters
- Code: mimic markdown (backticks)
- Math: output raw TeX
- Link, Image: recurse into content only (no \![], [])
- Cite: recurse into content
- Insert, Delete, Highlight, EditComment: recurse
- Note: skip (no warning)
- RawInline: echo if 'plaintext', else drop with warning
- Shortcode, NoteReference, Attr: drop with warning

## Blocks - Mimic markdown writer:
- Plain, Paragraph, Header: write inlines
- CodeBlock: fenced with backticks
- BlockQuote: > prefix
- LineBlock: | prefix
- OrderedList: 1. 2. 3.
- BulletList: - prefix
- HorizontalRule: ---
- Div, Figure: write contents only
- RawBlock: echo if 'plaintext', else drop with warning

## Blocks - Drop with warning:
- DefinitionList, Table: complex structure
- BlockMetadata, NoteDefinitionPara, NoteDefinitionFencedBlock, CaptionBlock: Quarto extensions
notes:
Design decisions:
1. RawInline/RawBlock: echo contents if format is 'plaintext', otherwise drop with warning
2. Add PlainTextWriterContext for threading error diagnostics
3. Issue diagnostic warnings on dropped nodes:
   - RawInline/RawBlock with mismatched formats (not 'plaintext')
   - Unsupported Quarto extensions: Shortcode, NoteReference, Attr (inlines), BlockMetadata, NoteDefinitionPara, NoteDefinitionFencedBlock, CaptionBlock (blocks)

Consider changing to Rc<SourceInfo> or Arc<SourceInfo> to make cloning cheap (reference counting). Need to study: serialization implications, thread-safety requirements, and performance benchmarks.
notes:
RECOMMENDATION: Use Rc<SourceInfo> instead of Box<SourceInfo>.

Analysis in claude-notes/sourcemapping-rc-arc-analysis.md

Key findings:
- Serde supports Rc with 'rc' feature flag
- Serialization doesn't preserve sharing (acceptable)
- Rc preferred over Arc (no threading, faster)
- Expected 10-50x speedup for nested documents
- Easy migration to Arc if needed later

Implementation:
1. Add serde rc feature to Cargo.toml
2. Box<SourceInfo> → Rc<SourceInfo>
3. Box::new → Rc::new
4. Verify serialization tests pass

notes:
Design document: claude-notes/plans/2025-12-03-lua-runtime-abstraction-layer.md

## Key Design Decisions

Modeled after Deno's permission system (https://docs.deno.com/runtime/fundamentals/security/):

### SecurityPolicy Structure (Deno-aligned)
- `allow_read` / `deny_read` - File read paths (like --allow-read)
- `allow_write` / `deny_write` - File write paths (like --allow-write)
- `allow_net` / `deny_net` - Network hosts (like --allow-net)
- `allow_run` / `deny_run` - Programs to execute (like --allow-run)
- `allow_env` / `deny_env` - Environment variables (like --allow-env)
- `allow_cwd` - CWD operations (grouped with env, like Deno's chdir)
- `allow_sys` - System info APIs (like --allow-sys)

### Resolved Design Questions
1. **CWD handling**: Part of 'env' category; allow in native, deny in WASM, flag in sandboxed
2. **Async network**: Design for blocking now, note async as future consideration
3. **Module loading**: `require()` subject to file read permissions
4. **Error messages**: Detailed, actionable messages (Deno pattern)

### Key Patterns
- Deny takes precedence over allow (Deno pattern)
- Path wildcards supported (like `/home/user/*`)
- Env var suffix wildcards (like `AWS_*`)
- Replace Lua io/os modules with runtime-controlled versions

### Industry Research
- Deno: Mature model, full adoption of their patterns
- Node.js: Permission model in v23.5+, simpler than Deno
- Bun: No permission model yet (open issue #6617)

title: Investigate Lua filter traversal order (typewise multi-pass)
description:
Our current Lua filter implementation uses a single bottom-up pass, but Pandoc's typewise traversal does multiple passes:

1. First pass: ALL inline elements (Str, Emph, etc. + Inline fallback)
2. Then: Inlines list filter
3. Second pass: ALL block elements (Para, Header, etc. + Block fallback)
4. Then: Blocks list filter
5. Finally: Meta, then Pandoc

**Current behavior (filter.rs):**
- For each block, we process its inline children, then the block itself
- This is bottom-up within a single traversal

**Pandoc behavior (documented):**
- "Lua filter functions are run in the order: Inlines → Blocks → Meta → Pandoc"
- This suggests multiple passes over the document

**Tasks:**
1. Study Pandoc's Haskell source to understand exact traversal semantics
2. Write test cases comparing our output to Pandoc's for filters that depend on traversal order
3. Determine if the difference matters in practice
4. If needed, implement multi-pass traversal to match Pandoc

**Key files:**
- crates/quarto-markdown-pandoc/src/lua/filter.rs (apply_filter_to_block, apply_filter_to_inlines)
- crates/quarto-markdown-pandoc/src/lua/types.rs (walk_blocks_with_filter, walk_inlines_with_filter)

**Also verify:**
- Generic Inline/Block fallback priority (type-specific should win)
- Add tests for these behaviors

## Problem

The `quarto.warn(msg, elem)` and `quarto.error(msg, elem)` functions accept an optional AST element to attach source location information. However, this only works for elements **created by filters** (which have `FilterProvenance` source info), not elements **from the original document** (which have `SourceInfo::Original`).

This is a significant limitation because user-provided filters that want to act as linters cannot report warnings/errors about specific locations in the source document - they can only report the filter's own location.

## Root Cause

In `src/lua/diagnostics.rs`, the `source_info_to_path_line` function (lines 208-218) only handles `FilterProvenance`:

```rust
fn source_info_to_path_line(source_info: &SourceInfo) -> Option<(String, i64)> {
    match source_info {
        SourceInfo::FilterProvenance { filter_path, line } => {
            Some((filter_path.clone(), *line as i64))
        }
        // For Original source info, we don't have easy access to the filename
        // without a SourceContext. For now, return None to fall back to stack.
        _ => None,
    }
}
```

For `SourceInfo::Original`, we need access to `SourceContext` to:
1. Look up the `FileId` to get the filename
2. Map byte offsets to line/column numbers

The `SourceContext` is available in `ASTContext` but is not currently passed to the Lua diagnostic functions.

## How to Test

Create a test filter `linter.lua`:
```lua
function Str(elem)
    if elem.text:match('TODO') then
        quarto.warn('Found TODO in document', elem)
    end
    return elem
end
```

Create a test document `test.qmd`:
```markdown
This has a TODO item.
```

Run:
```bash
cargo run -- -L linter.lua -i test.qmd -t native
```

**Expected**: Warning shows location in `test.qmd` (line 1, around column 12)
**Actual**: Warning shows location in `linter.lua` (line 3, the quarto.warn call)

## Potential Solutions

1. **Pass ASTContext to Lua state**: Store `ASTContext` (or at least `SourceContext`) in the Lua registry so diagnostic functions can access it
2. **Thread-local context**: Use a thread-local to store context during filter execution
3. **Closure capture**: Capture context in the Lua function closures created in `register_quarto_namespace`

Option 1 or 3 seems cleanest. The context would need to be set before filter execution and cleared after.

## Related

- Parent issue: k-480 (Implement quarto.warn/error Lua functions)
- Plan: claude-notes/plans/2025-12-03-lua-filter-diagnostics-implementation.md
- Discussion: Element location extraction was identified as incomplete during implementation review
notes:
Plan document: claude-notes/plans/2025-12-03-k481-source-location-resolution.md

FINAL APPROACH: Store SourceInfo as Lua table (not userdata)

Why not userdata?
- In Pandoc, userdata = AST nodes. Filters may use type(x)=='userdata' to identify elements.
- Using userdata for non-AST data could cause Pandoc compatibility issues.

Why not thread-local IDs?  
- If diagnostic entries are serialized, IDs become meaningless.

Solution: Serialize SourceInfo to plain Lua table, deserialize on extraction.

Lua table format:
  { t = 'Original', file_id = 0, start_offset = 42, end_offset = 55 }
  { t = 'Substring', parent = {...}, start_offset = 10, end_offset = 20 }
  { t = 'FilterProvenance', filter_path = '...', line = 42 }

Changes needed in diagnostics.rs:
1. Add source_info_to_lua_table() and source_info_from_lua_table()
2. Update add_diagnostic() to store serialized SourceInfo
3. Update extract_lua_diagnostics() to deserialize and pass to builder
4. Remove obsolete resolution functions

Benefits:
- No SourceContext needed in Lua
- Pure Lua tables (Pandoc-compatible)
- Serialization-safe
- Resolution stays in Rust

title: Filesystem synchronization design for quarto-hub
description:
Design the bidirectional synchronization between filesystem (.qmd files) and automerge documents.

## Core Design: Unified Sync Algorithm

A single fork-and-merge algorithm handles ALL sync scenarios (startup, shutdown, periodic, user-triggered):

1. Fork doc at last sync checkpoint
2. Apply filesystem content to fork via update_text (Myers diff)
3. Merge fork back into main doc (CRDT merge)
4. Write merged result to filesystem
5. Update checkpoint

This naturally handles: no changes (no-op), automerge-only changes, filesystem-only changes, and true divergence (three-way merge).

## Key Decisions
- Automerge update_text handles diffing internally (grapheme-aware Myers)
- Sync state stored locally in sync-state.json (not synced to peers)
- Algorithm converges: after sync, fs and automerge match

## Related Issues
- k-r2t1 (filesystem serialization strategy)
- k-yvfo (conflict resolution for divergence)

title: Audit anyhow::anyhow\! usages for error structure loss
description:
Several places in the codebase use anyhow::anyhow\!() in ways that lose structured error information. This issue tracks reviewing and potentially fixing these patterns.

## Problematic Patterns Found

### qmd-syntax-helper crate

1. **syntax_check.rs:89** - Joins error strings and wraps in anyhow:
   ```rust
   let error_msg = errors.join("\n");
   Err(anyhow::anyhow\!("{}", error_msg))
   ```

2. **grid_tables.rs:137** - Uses debug format on diagnostics:
   ```rust
   anyhow::anyhow\!("Failed to write markdown output: {:?}", diagnostics)
   ```

3. **definition_lists.rs:190** - Same issue as grid_tables.rs

### validate-yaml crate

- Uses anyhow for simple CLI errors, likely acceptable for a validation tool.

## Recommended Actions

1. For qmd-syntax-helper: Consider using proper diagnostic rendering with `to_text()` instead of debug format
2. Review if these tools need the same rich error display as the main CLI
3. Consider creating a shared error display utility

## Notes

- Simple IO/path errors using anyhow are acceptable
- The main render.rs:201 issue was fixed separately (handled parse errors specially to avoid duplicate 'Error:' prefix)

title: Design structural hash-based AST reconciliation algorithm
description:
Design a reconciliation algorithm for PandocAST nodes inspired by React 15's reconciliation. Use structural hashes as virtual keys for node identity since we don't have explicit id keys. The hash of a node = hash(type, content, children_hashes), excluding source locations. This enables O(n) reconciliation with efficient subtree skipping when hashes match.

Approach:
- Compute structural hashes for both pre-engine and post-engine ASTs
- Hash serves as 'virtual key' for matching nodes across ASTs
- If hashes match, subtrees are identical - transfer source locations wholesale
- If hashes differ but types match, recurse into children
- Use hash-based alignment for children lists (hash -> node multimap)

Plan: claude-notes/plans/2025-12-17-structural-hash-reconciliation-design.md
